Post Description:
Phase 3 begins today. Families will now have the chance to gather in a larger group of 8, and enjoy some meaningful time together.

But please remember: there are still rules in Phase 3. So comply with the measures and do not let your guard down. Around the world, some experts are already warning about a post-seasonal surge in cases, as people are ignoring the restrictions and flocking together for festive celebrations. We must not allow that to happen here.

I thank the majority of residents here who are doing their part. Unfortunately there are a few who continue to disregard the rules. Some book multiple tables in restaurants; others hold large parties in their homes. We will step up enforcement checks, and will take firm actions against these breaches, even for first-time offences - business outlets will be closed, individuals fined, and as highlighted before, those who are work-pass holders risk getting their passes revoked.

Let‚Äôs stay focused and get through the next few months safely, until we are able to get everyone in Singapore vaccinated.
Comments: There are families having parties of 10 pax even way before phase 2 was over...

Post Description:
It‚Äôs the second day of our Phase 2 re-opening, and the majority of businesses and individuals are cooperating with the measures to resume activities safely. But unfortunately a few have acted very irresponsibly. They will be taken to task. 
Last night, the authorities were alerted to large crowds gathering around the Outdoor Refreshment Areas (ORA) and on the road along Lor Mambong in Holland Village.  Based on their inspections, the crowds were largely gathering outside one restaurant, namely the British Indian Curry Hut. We will close the restaurant with immediate effect.
All ORAs along Lor Mambong will also be removed. So F&B outlets along this stretch will have to ensure that their customers dine only within their premises, and are not eating or drinking outside. 
Enforcement officers have also issued fines to several individuals in the vicinity last night for violating safe distancing rules. Investigations are ongoing for other possible breaches.
Our officers will continue their patrols islandwide, especially in popular nightspots, and will take immediate actions against any individuals or business flouting the safe distancing rules.
Comments: Pls consider banning alcohol at F&B, for the same reason why entertainment outlets are not allowed in phase 2.

Post Description:
Singapore will be entering Phase 2 of reopening after 18 June 2359. This means that from Friday onwards, almost all businesses will be able to re-open, be it retail, F&B dining-in or personalised consumer services. The key requirement is that individuals must maintain safe distancing of at least 1 m at all times, and if that‚Äôs not feasible (eg when dining at a table), then each group will be limited to a maximum of 5 persons. Sports, gyms, playgrounds, and other public facilities will open, as will similar facilities in condominiums and clubs. Small group gatherings of up to any 5 persons can also resume, and households may receive up to 5 visitors at any time. 
There are a small number of activities that will take more time to resume. These are activities where large numbers of people are likely to come into close contact, often in enclosed spaces and for prolonged periods of time. They include religious services and congregations; large-scale events and venues; and entertainment outlets like bars, clubs and karaoke outlets. We will continue to work with these organisations and business owners on the safe management measures that are needed before they can open.
Phase 2 is a significant step forward in our reopening process. But please do not treat this as a signal to relax and let our guard down. 
Businesses must take the rules seriously. Do not rush to open if you are not ready, because you will be putting your own customers and employees at risk. All of us must continue to exercise individual and social responsibility. There‚Äôs no need to rush to go out this weekend. We should continue to limit our close contacts, even if we can now meet in groups. As customers, we should also be discerning about the establishments we patronise, and insist on high safety standards everywhere we go.

Let‚Äôs continue to work together on this collective journey to achieve a Covid-safe Singapore!
Comments: Thank you sir Lawrence for all the hard work you and your team had put to keep us safe....and bug thank you for initiating phase 2.

Post Description:
As we approach the end of the circuit breaker, we are now preparing for the next phase and considering what activities can resume in a safe manner.  We will do so in a very careful and calibrated manner. It won‚Äôt simply be a return to life before the circuit breaker. 
For example, in the construction sector, we will only re-start with a few projects and insist on very tight end-to-end safeguards for these projects. The safeguards include requiring all the workers involved in a project to be housed together (instead of being at multiple dormitories); safe distancing measures at the work sites; and periodic testing of the workers (at 2 week intervals). We expect only about 5% of the construction workforce to work on these projects, and will scale up over time as the industry gains confidence and experience with the measures. 
We will apply this same calibrated approach in how we resume normal activities, be it at work, schools, or in our social settings. In other words, don‚Äôt expect 100% resumption of activities after 1 June. On the contrary, be fully prepared that many of the current restrictions and measures we have today will continue for some time, so as to keep our family members and loved ones safe. 
A controlled and phased exit from the circuit breaker will require patience and discipline from all of us. We must all do our part to control the spread of the virus and ensure that it does not flare up again.
Comments: Dear Lawrence Wong, don‚Äôt say patience when you do not know what livelihood you are destroying. You are simply extending the CB for many of our businesses while you allow others to open based on some contact logic. In the first place if the government had given quarantine for those coming back instead of just SHN or deal with overcrowding dorms and not let those people running dorms get away with it! Now you make us pay the price and announce like the 75% help us a lot!? I don‚Äôt mind eating basic meals and not even spending any money but if you destroy my kids future and my hard work for them, I get very angry. What right do you have destroying people‚Äôs livelihoods? It‚Äôs not just me that is angry but virtually all my close to 100 workers and many many of my colleagues and friends affected. You want to put spa in phase 2 or 3 and let us bleed indefinitely when the local numbers is down to 1-2 a day but allow pet grooming and hair salon to open??? What‚Äôs the logic in there? What rights do you have to destroy people‚Äôs livelihoods?

Post Description:

‚†Ä
My speech will be livestreamed on my Facebook Page (www.facebook.com/leehsienloong) at 5pm on Monday, 14 December. You can also catch it live on @mediacorp TV channels and radio. Do tune in! ‚†Ä

Post Description:
You all heard the news: Phase 2 of re-opening starts this Friday, 19 June.

It is a significant step. Most activities will resume, except certain larger scale ones with close interaction activities, that have potential to be mass spreading events. Social gatherings should have a maximum of five people. 
All the things we miss - sitting in coffeeshops or restaurants, bubble tea, tuition and enrichment classes, meeting up with boyfriends or girlfriends, can all resume. 
It took us a lot of sacrifice to get here, after a fairly long circuit breaker period, and a careful Phase 1 opening. But during this time, all of us co-operated, and we suppressed the virus transmission. 
From here, it is up to us again. We will all take care of our personal hygiene, adopt necessary precautionary measures, look out for one another. That way, we keep the virus under control in Phase 2. While we are all eager to meet up with friends and socialise, we will do so safely. No need to all rush out on Friday - everywhere will be full. Can take our time a bit, and ease into our social activities again. My daughter already told me I must wait for my Father√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s Day dinner. 
Schools will continue with our weekly rotation plan, and comprehensive safe management measures. We will bring all students back daily from 29 June. MOE will give more details soon.

Have fun but stay safe! (Photo taken before COVID-19.)
